paragraphs.zh-tw: My name is Joseph,a Member of Parliament in Kenya. Picture a Maasai village, and one evening, government soldiers come,surround the village and ask each elder to bringone boy to school. That's how I went to school -- pretty much a government guypointing a gun and told my father,"You have to make a choice." I walked very comfortablyto this missionary school, that was run by an American missionary.
paragraphs.en: 我的名字是喬瑟夫，我是肯亞的國會議員。 你們試著想像一下，在肯亞的馬塞村， 有天晚上，政府的軍隊來了，包圍整個村莊， 然後要每一個長者帶一個小男孩去上學， 那就是我去上學的原因-- 就像有個在政府上班的傢伙，拿著一把槍， 對我父親說：「你得做出決定。」 就這樣，我很愉快地去上傳教士開的學校， 那是由美國的傳教士所開設的學校，

paragraphs.zh-tw: The first thing the American missionarygave me was a candy. I had never in my life ever tasted candy.
paragraphs.en: 而美國傳教士給我的第一樣東西就是一顆糖果。 在那之前，我從未吃過糖果。

paragraphs.zh-tw: So I said to myself,with all these hundred other boys, this is where I belong. I stayed.
paragraphs.en: 所以我對我自己說，儘管這裡有其他一百多個男孩子， 這就是我要待的地方，待下來--

paragraphs.zh-tw: When everybody else was dropping out. My family moved; we're nomads.
paragraphs.en: --直到別人都退出為止。 我父母不停地搬家，因為我們是遊牧民族，

paragraphs.zh-tw: It was a boarding school, I was seven -- Every time it closedyou had to travel to find them. 40-50 miles, it doesn't matter.
paragraphs.en: 而每當學期結束--那是一所寄宿學校，我那時七歲-- 我就得一直找，直到找到我的家人為止。 50哩路、40哩路，我不管，

paragraphs.zh-tw: You slept in the bush, but you kept going. And I stayed. I don't know why, but I did.
paragraphs.en: 就算睡在樹叢裡，還是得繼續走。 我不知道我為什麼要待在那所學校，但我還是待下來了。

paragraphs.zh-tw: All of a sudden I passedthe national examination, found myself in a very beautifulhigh school in Kenya. And I finished high school.
paragraphs.en: 一轉眼間，我通過了國家考試， 我置身於肯亞一所非常美麗的高中，

paragraphs.zh-tw: And just walking, I found a man who gave me a full scholarshipto the United States. My mother still lived in a cow-dung hut, none of my brothers were going to school, and this man told me, "Here, go." I got a scholarship to St. Lawrence University,Upstate New York; finished that.
paragraphs.en: 接著我完成了高中學業，然後有一個人 提供給我全額的獎學金，讓我去美國唸書。 我母親現在還住在一個用牛糞糊的小棚屋裡， 我的兄弟沒有人上過學校， 但這個人告訴我：「去吧。」 所以我拿了獎學金到紐約州北部的聖羅倫斯大學，

paragraphs.zh-tw: And after that I wentto Harvard Graduate School; finished that. Then I worked in DC a little bit: I wrote a book for National Geographicand taught U.S. history.
paragraphs.en: 完成學業之後，我又去哈佛唸了研究所； 研究所畢業之後，我到華盛頓特區工作了一陣子。 我為國家地理雜誌撰寫了一本書，並教授歷史，美國歷史。

paragraphs.zh-tw: And every time, I kept going back home, listening to their problems -- sick people, peoplewith no water, all this stuff -- every time I go back to America, I kept thinking about them. Then one day, an elder gave mea story that went like this: long time ago, there was a big warbetween tribes.
paragraphs.en: 每當我回到家鄉來， 聆聽家鄉人民訴苦， 有的人生病，有的人缺水，這一類的問題不斷。 每當我再回到美國時，我仍忍不住想起家鄉的人。 然後有一天，一個老者告訴了我一個故事，故事是這樣的： 很久以前，在二個部落裡發生了戰爭，

paragraphs.zh-tw: This specific tribe was really afraidof this other Luhya tribe. Every time, they sent scoutsto make sure no one attacked them.
paragraphs.en: 其中一個部落很怕另一個路西亞部落， 所以每一次他們都派偵察員去看對方是否來襲。

paragraphs.zh-tw: So one day, the scouts came runningand told the villagers, "The enemies are coming.Only half an hour away, they'll be here." So people scrambled, took their thingsand ready to go, move out. But there were two men: one man was blind, one man had no legs -- he was born like that.
paragraphs.en: 有一天，偵察員跑回來告訴村民： 「敵人來了，只有半個小時的距離--他們就要來了！」 大家亂成一團，趕忙收拾東西，準備逃走。 但有二個人， 一個是瞎子，一個天生就沒了兩條腿，

paragraphs.zh-tw: The leader of the chiefs said, "No, sorry.We can't take you. You'll slow us down. We have to flee our womenand children, we have to run." And they were left behind, waiting to die.
paragraphs.en: 族長對他們說：「對不起，我們不能帶你們走，你們會拖累我們， 我們得疏散女人和小孩，我們要走了。」 所以他們就被留下來等死。

paragraphs.zh-tw: But these two people worked something out. The blind man said, "Look,I'm a very strong man but I can't see." The man with no legs says,"I can see as far as the end of the world, but I can't save myselffrom a cat, or whatever animals." The blind man went downon his knees like this, and told the man with no legsto go over his back, and stood up.
paragraphs.en: 但這二個人想出了一個辦法。 瞎子說：「你看，雖然我看不到，但我很強壯。」 沒腿的人說：「我的視力好到可以看到世界的盡頭， 但我卻沒辦法從一隻貓身邊逃開，更別說其他動物了。」 這時瞎子蹲下身來，像這樣， 要沒腿的人爬到他的背上，然後站起身來。

paragraphs.zh-tw: The man on top can see,the blind man can walk. These guys took off, followedthe footsteps of the villagers until they found and passed them.
paragraphs.en: 在上面的人看得很清楚，瞎子則可以走路， 所以這二個人循著其他村民的腳印出發了， 他們追上了其他村民，還超越了他們。

paragraphs.zh-tw: So, this was told to mein a setup of elders. And it's a really poor area.
paragraphs.en: 這是我在老人之家聽來的故事， 那個地區很貧窮，我代表的是北肯亞--

paragraphs.zh-tw: I represent Northern Kenya: the most nomadic, remote areasyou can even find. And that man told me, "So, here you are.
paragraphs.en: 大部分是遊牧民放，在最遙遠的地方。 那個人告訴我：「你現在在這裡，

paragraphs.zh-tw: You've got a good education from America,you have a good life in America; what are you going to do for us? We want you to be our eyes,we'll give you the legs. We'll walk you, you lead us." The opportunity came.I was always thinking about that: "What can I do to help my people? Every time you go to an areawhere for 43 years of independence, we still don't havebasic health facilities.
paragraphs.en: 你受過美國良好的教育， 你在美國有好的生活，你究竟要為我們做什麼？ 我們希望你能當我們的眼睛，我們會當你的腳， 我們會幫你跑腿，你只要帶領我們就行了。」 機會來了，那是我一直在思考的事情， 我可以為家鄉的人做些什麼？ 每次我到這個已經獨立43年的地區來時， 都發現我們還是沒有基本的醫療設施。

paragraphs.zh-tw: A man has to be transportedin a wheelbarrow 30 km for a hospital. No clean drinking water.
paragraphs.en: 我們必須用獨輪車把病人運送到 20或30公里以外的醫院去，我們也沒有乾淨的飲用水。

paragraphs.zh-tw: So I said, "I'm going to dedicate myself. I'm leaving America.
paragraphs.en: 所以我說：「我要奉獻我自己，

paragraphs.zh-tw: I'm going to run for office." Last June, I moved from America, ran in July election and won. And I came for them, and that's my goal.
paragraphs.en: 我會離開美國，我要參加競選。」 所以去年七月--我在六月離開美國，七月投入選舉並獲選為國會議員。 我是為家鄉的人民回來的，那是我的目標。

paragraphs.zh-tw: Right now I have in place,for the last nine months, a plan that in five years, every nomad will haveclean drinking water. We're building dispensariesacross that constituency.
paragraphs.en: 現在，我已經籌劃了九個月了， 我希望在未來五年內，每一個牧人都可以享有乾淨的飲用水。 我們在選區裡設置了幾個診療所，

paragraphs.zh-tw: I'm asking my friends from America to help with bringing nursesor doctors to help us out. I'm trying to improve infrastructure.
paragraphs.en: 我還請在美國的朋友幫忙， 希望他們能帶護士或醫生來幫我們。 我正在著手改善基礎建設，

paragraphs.zh-tw: I'm using the knowledgeI received from the United States and from my community to move them forward. I'm trying to develophomegrown solutions to our issues because people from outsidecan come and help us, but if we don't help ourselves,there's nothing to do.
paragraphs.en: 我運用了我在美國所學得的知識， 以及我從社區裡學來的知識，推動這些基礎建設。 我希望能以肯亞自己的方式來解決自己的問題， 因為我們知道，外界的人或許可以幫助我們， 但若我們自己都不幫自己，那我們就做不成任何事。

paragraphs.zh-tw: My plan right now as I continue with introducingstudents to different fields -- some become doctors, some lawyers -- we want to producea comprehensive group of people, students who can come backand help us see a community grow that is in the middleof a huge economic recession. As I continue to bea Member of Parliament and as I continue listeningto all of you talking about botany, health, democracy, new inventions, I'm hoping that one dayin my own little community -- which is 26,000 square km, maybe five times Rhode Island -- with no roads, we'll be able to become a modelto help others develop.
paragraphs.en: 我現在的計畫是，我會繼續讓學生在各種學科裡學習， 讓他們變成醫生，變成律師， 我希望我們的學生能學會多種技能， 最後回來家鄉幫助這個社區成長。 雖然我們正經歷巨大的經濟衰退， 只要我還擔任國會議員一天， 只要我還繼續聆聽你們的聲音一天，不管你們談的是植物、 健康、民主或新的發明， 我希望總有一天，我們這個小小的社區-- 縱然只有二萬六千平方公里， 或許只有羅德島的五倍大，也沒有道路-- 能夠成為其他社區發展的楷模。

paragraphs.zh-tw: Thank you very much.
paragraphs.en: 謝謝你們。

title: Joseph Lekuton Tells A Parable For Kenya
